title: AI in Workforce Development
subtitle: Sample Demo ‚Äî Exploring GenAI's Impact on Regional Employment

talking_points.label: Opening
talking_points.question: The Big Picture: Why This Research Matters Now
talking_points.note:
Generative AI tools like ChatGPT and Copilot are transforming how firms recruit, screen, and hire workers. But we know very little about how this is playing out in regional labor markets outside major tech hubs.

Our research will produce the first systematic analysis of GenAI adoption among employers in a mid-sized metro area, giving policymakers and educators actionable data.

‚Üí Let me walk you through how we plan to do this...
talking_points.tip_do: Connect to the audience's local context ‚Äî they care about their region.
talking_points.tip_dont: Don't lead with technical jargon or national statistics they've already seen.

talking_points.label: Problem
talking_points.question: The Research Gap We're Filling
talking_points.note:
Existing AI workforce research focuses on coastal tech corridors. No peer-reviewed study has examined how small and mid-sized employers in areas like ours are integrating GenAI into their hiring pipelines.

Without this data, regional development agencies are making investment decisions in the dark.

‚Üí Here's our approach to closing this gap...
talking_points.tip_do: Use a brief anecdote from a local employer you've spoken with.
talking_points.tip_dont: Don't overstate the crisis ‚Äî be measured and evidence-based.

talking_points.label: Methods
talking_points.question: Three Research Aims ‚Üí One Clear Picture
talking_points.note:
Aim 1: Survey 500+ regional employers across 12 counties to measure current GenAI adoption in hiring.

Aim 2: Conduct 30 in-depth interviews with HR directors and hiring managers to understand the 'how' and 'why' behind adoption.

Aim 3: Build a public AI Readiness Dashboard that benchmarks our region against national trends.

‚Üí Let me show you what we'll deliver...
talking_points.tip_do: Emphasize the mixed-methods approach ‚Äî it's a strength.
talking_points.tip_dont: Don't get lost in methodological details; save that for Q&A.

talking_points.label: Budget
talking_points.question: Budget & Team Qualifications
talking_points.note:
The total budget of $85,000 covers: survey infrastructure ($15K), research assistants ($30K), PI summer salary ($25K), and dashboard development ($15K).

Our team combines economics expertise with industry connections ‚Äî we already have commitments from 3 regional chambers of commerce to help with employer recruitment.
talking_points.tip_do: Highlight the partnerships ‚Äî they demonstrate feasibility.
talking_points.tip_dont: Don't apologize for the budget amount; it's well-justified.

talking_points.label: Close
talking_points.question: The Ask & Expected Impact
talking_points.note:
With this funding, we will produce the region's first AI workforce readiness report, a peer-reviewed publication, and an open-access dashboard used by workforce boards and economic development agencies.

This is an investment in understanding how our region navigates the AI transition ‚Äî not just documenting it, but equipping decision-makers to lead it.
talking_points.tip_do: End with confidence ‚Äî restate the value proposition clearly.
talking_points.tip_dont: Don't rush the close. Let the impact statement land.

practice_questions.q: What makes this proposal different from existing AI workforce studies?
points: Regional focus ‚Äî no comparable study exists for mid-sized metros
Mixed methods: quantitative survey + qualitative interviews
Actionable output: public dashboard, not just a paper
Existing community partnerships reduce recruitment risk

practice_questions.q: How will you achieve a 500-employer survey response rate?
points: Three chamber of commerce partners already committed
Targeted LinkedIn and email outreach by industry sector
Incentive structure: summary report + dashboard access for participants
Prior survey work by PI achieved 38% response rate in the region

practice_questions.q: What will the AI Readiness Dashboard actually show?
points: Adoption rates by industry, firm size, and county
Skills gap analysis: GenAI skills demanded vs. available
Interactive map with county-level benchmarks
Open-source, hosted at the university for long-term access

practice_questions.q: How does this benefit students and the university?
points: Research assistantship for 2 graduate students
Curriculum data for departments considering AI integration
Co-authorship opportunity for student researchers
Dashboard becomes a teaching tool in economics and business courses

practice_questions.q: What happens if GenAI adoption turns out to be very low in the region?
points: Low adoption is itself a significant finding ‚Äî it signals a readiness gap
The dashboard would highlight where intervention is most needed
Qualitative interviews will capture barriers and concerns
Findings still publishable and policy-relevant regardless of direction

practice_questions.q: Why should we fund this now rather than waiting?
points: GenAI adoption is accelerating ‚Äî Q1 2026 is a critical measurement window
Early data positions the university as a regional thought leader
Waiting means missing the adoption curve and playing catch-up
Other regions are already commissioning similar studies

tips: Know your 3 aims cold ‚Äî they're the spine of the pitch.
Pause after key statistics. Let the audience absorb them.
Make eye contact with each panel member at least once.
If you don't know an answer, say "Great question ‚Äî I'll follow up with specifics."
Keep the energy conversational, not lecture-style.
Practice the 2-minute pitch variant until it feels effortless.
Mention the community partnerships early ‚Äî they signal credibility.
End 30 seconds early to invite questions. Panelists love that.

pitch_variants.30sec: We're studying how generative AI is reshaping hiring in our region. Through a 500-employer survey, 30 qualitative interviews, and a public AI Readiness Dashboard, we'll give workforce leaders the first real data on regional GenAI adoption ‚Äî an $85K investment that positions our university as the go-to resource on AI and employment.
pitch_variants.60sec: Generative AI is transforming how companies recruit and hire, but all the research focuses on big coastal metros. No one has studied what's happening in regions like ours. We propose a rigorous mixed-methods study: a 500-employer survey across 12 counties, 30 in-depth interviews with HR directors, and a public AI Readiness Dashboard. Three chambers of commerce are already on board. For $85,000 over 18 months, we'll deliver a peer-reviewed publication, a policy brief, and the region's first AI workforce readiness report. This is about equipping our community to navigate the AI transition with data, not assumptions.
pitch_variants.2min:
Thank you for your time. Let me tell you about a gap that's costing our region ‚Äî not money, but insight.

Generative AI tools like ChatGPT are now embedded in hiring at major corporations. McKinsey reports 72% of large firms have adopted GenAI in some HR function. But here's the problem: we have zero data on what's happening in mid-sized metros like ours.

Are local employers using AI to screen resumes? To write job descriptions? Are they skipping it entirely? We don't know ‚Äî and neither do the workforce boards and economic development agencies making investment decisions for our region.

Our proposal fills this gap with three aims. First, we'll survey 500+ employers across 12 counties ‚Äî we already have three chambers of commerce committed to recruitment. Second, we'll interview 30 HR directors in depth to understand not just 'if' but 'how' and 'why.' Third, we'll build a public AI Readiness Dashboard ‚Äî interactive, open-access, and designed for policymakers.

The total cost is $85,000 over 18 months. Our team has the expertise, the partnerships, and the track record. This isn't just a research project ‚Äî it's a public resource that positions our university as the regional authority on AI and workforce development.

I'd be happy to take any questions.

key_messages: First regional study of GenAI adoption in hiring ‚Äî no comparable data exists
Mixed methods: 500-employer survey + 30 in-depth interviews = rigorous evidence
Public AI Readiness Dashboard ‚Äî actionable, open-access, long-lived
Three community partners already committed ‚Äî this is a collaborative effort
$85K is a modest investment for a major regional resource
Deliverables include a peer-reviewed publication and a policy brief

objections.objection: Isn't this research already being done at the national level?
objections.response: National studies aggregate data that erases regional variation. A 72% adoption rate nationally could mean 90% in San Francisco and 20% here. Our study provides the granular, local data that actually informs regional policy.

objections.objection: How do you know employers will respond to the survey?
objections.response: We have written commitments from three chambers of commerce to co-distribute the survey. My prior regional employer survey achieved a 38% response rate, well above the typical 15-20% for business surveys.

objections.objection: What's the sustainability plan for the dashboard after funding ends?
objections.response: The dashboard will be hosted on university infrastructure at minimal cost. We're building it with open-source tools, and the Hibbs Institute has committed to maintaining it as a core public resource.

objections.objection: Why not just focus on the survey without the interviews?
objections.response: Surveys tell us 'what' and 'how much,' but not 'why.' The qualitative interviews will reveal the motivations, barriers, and concerns behind adoption decisions ‚Äî that's what makes policy recommendations credible.
